div.p: THE COPIE OF A LETTER SENT OVT OF ENGLAND TO AN AMBASSADOUR in FRANCE for the KING of SPAINE, declaring the State of ENGLAND contrary to the opinion of Don Bernardin, and of all his partizans Spaniards and others.

Wherunto are adioyned certain Adverti≈øements, concerning the lo≈ø≈øes and distre≈ø≈øes happened to the Spani≈øh Navy, as well in fight with the Engli≈øh Navie in the narrow Seas of England; as al≈øo by tempe≈øts and contrary winds, upon the We≈øt and North coa≈øts of Ireland, in their returne from the Northerne I≈øles beyond Scotland.

div.head: The Printer to the Reader.
div.p: ALthough it be well known, that neither the fir≈øt writers of the≈øe Letters now by me printed, nor yet the Spaniard Don Bernardin to whom they are directed had any de≈øire to heare of any good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe to the State of England: as may appeare in the writer, by ≈øhewing him≈øelfe grieved, to make any good report of England, other then of meere nece≈ø≈øity he was urged: And in Don Bernardin, who was ≈øo impudent, or at the lea≈øt, ≈øo blindly ra≈øh, as to disper≈øe in print, both in French, Italian and Spani≈øh, mo≈øt fal≈øe reports of a victory had by the Spaniards, even when the victory was notable on the part of England, and the Spani≈øh vanqui≈øhed; yet whil≈øt I was occupied in the printing heerof, a good time after the Letters were ≈øent into France, there came to this City certaine knowledge, to all our great comfort, of ≈øundry happy Accidents, to the diminution of our mortall enemies in their famous Fleet, that was driven out of our Seas about the la≈øt of July, 1588 towards the farthermo≈øt North parts of Scotland. Wherefore I have thought it not ami≈ø≈øe to joyne the ≈øame to this Letter of Don Bernardin, that he may beware not to be ≈øo ha≈øty of him≈øelfe, nor yet to permit one Capella, who is his common ≈øower of reports to write the≈øe fal≈øe things for truthes.

The particularities whereof are the≈øe. The Fleet was by tempe≈øt driven beyond the I≈øles of Orknay, about the fir≈øt of Augu≈øt, 1588. the place being aboue three≈øcore degrees from the North Pole: an unaccu≈øtomed place for the young Gallants of Spaine, that never had felt ≈øtormes on the Sea, or cold weather in Augu≈øt. And about tho≈øe North I≈ølands, their Mariners and Souldiers died daily by multitudes; as by their bodies ca≈øt on land did appeare. And after twenty daies or more, having ≈øpent their time in mi≈øeries, they being de≈øirous to returne home to Spain, ≈øailed very farre Southwe≈øtward into the Ocean to recover Spaine. But the Almighty God, who alwaies avengeth the cau≈øe of his afflicted people which put their confidence in him, and bringeth downe his enemies that exalt them≈øelves with pride to the Heavens, ordered the windes to be ≈øo violently contrarious to this proud Navie, as it was with force di≈ø≈øevered on the high Seas We≈øt upon Ireland: and ≈øo a great number of them, driven into ≈øundry dangerous bayes, and upon rockes, all along the We≈øt and North parts of Ireland, in ≈øundry places di≈øtant above an hundred miles a≈øunder, and there ca≈øt away, ≈øome ≈øunke, ≈øome broken, ≈øome run on ≈øands, ≈øome burned by the Spaniards them≈øelves.

As in the North part of Ireland towards Scotland, betwixt the two rivers of Loughfo ‚Ä¢ le and Lough Swilley, nine were driven to land, and many of them broken, and the Spaniards forced to come to land for ≈øuccour among≈øt the wilde Iri≈øh.

In another place, twenty miles South-we≈øt from thence, in a Bay called
Calbeggy, three other ≈øhips driven al≈øo upon rockes. In another place Southward, being a Bay called the Borreys, twentie miles North from G ‚Ä¢ llowey belonging to the Earle of Ormond, one ≈øpeciall great Ship of a thou≈øand tunne, with fifty bra≈ø≈øe peeces and foure Cannons was ≈øunke, and all the people drowned ≈øaving ≈øixteene: who by their apparell, as it is adverti≈øed out of Ireland, ≈øeeme to be per≈øons of great e≈øtimation.

Then to come more to the Southward, thirtie miles upon the coa≈øts of Thomond, North from the river Shennan, two or three moe peri≈øhed, whereof one was burned by the Spaniards them≈øelves and ≈øo driven to the ≈øhore: another was of S. Seba≈øtians, wherin were three hundred men, who were al≈øo all drowned ≈øaving three≈øcore. A third Ship with all her lading was ca≈øt away at a place called Breckan.

In another place afore Sir Tirlogh Obrynes hou≈øe, there was al≈øo another great Ship lo≈øt, ≈øuppo≈øed to be a Gallia≈ø≈øe The≈øe lo≈ø≈øes above mentioned, were betwixt the fift and tenth of September, as was adverti≈øed from ≈øundry places out of Ireland: ≈øo as by account, from the one and twentieth of July, when this Navy was fir≈øt beaten with the Navie of England, untill the tenth of September, being the ≈øpace of ≈øeven weekes and more, it is mo≈øt likely that the ≈øaid Navie had never good day nor night

Of the re≈øt of the Navie, report is al≈øo made that many of them have bene ≈øeene, lying of and on upon the coa≈øt of Ireland, to≈ø≈øed with the windes, in ≈øuch ≈øort as it is al≈øo doubted, that many of them ≈øhall hardly recover Spaine, if they be ≈øo weakned with lacke of victuals and Mariners, as part of their companies that were left on land do lamentably report. The≈øe accidents I thought good to adde to the printed Copies of the Letters of Don Bernardin, that he may ≈øee how God doth favour the ju≈øt cau≈øe of that gracious Queen, in ≈øhewing his anger towards tho≈øe proud boa≈øting enemies of Chri≈øtian peace, as the whole world, from Rome to the uttermo≈øt parts of Chri≈øtendome may ≈øee, that ≈øhe and her Realme, profe≈ø≈øing the Gospell of his ≈øonne Chri≈øt were kept and defended, as the words of the P≈øalme are, Under the ≈øhadow of his wings from the face of the wicked that ≈øought to afflict her, and compa≈ø≈øe her round about to take away her ≈øoule: Which I doubt not, by thankfullne≈ø≈øe yeelded by her Maje≈øtie and her whole Realme, will alwaies cotinue.
